title: 109_hr4942
content: The Act may be cited as the "Promoting Antiterrorism Capabilities Through International Cooperation Act". The Congress acknowledges the importance of technology in combating terrorism and implementing homeland security strategies. The US and its allies in the global war on terrorism have a shared interest in developing technologies for detecting, preventing, and responding to acts of terrorism. Certain allies like Israel, the UK, Canada, Australia, and Singapore have expertise in homeland security. The United States and its allies in the global war on terrorism collaborate on developing beneficial technologies in defense, agriculture, and telecommunications. Sharing technological expertise will help combat domestic and international terrorism, safeguarding lives and property worldwide. SEC. 314 of the Homeland Security Act of 2002 introduces the Promoting Antiterrorism Through International Cooperation Program. The term 'Director' in this section refers to the Director selected under subsection (c)(1). 'International cooperative activities' encompass various collaborative projects such as research, joint ventures, field exercises, training, exchanges of personnel, sharing of information, and joint use of facilities and equipment. The Under Secretary for Science and Technology of the Department of Homeland Security is authorized to carry out international cooperative activities, including grants, agreements, and contracts with institutions of higher education. The Under Secretary for Science and Technology of the Department of Homeland Security is authorized to engage in cooperative agreements with various entities, ensuring equitable funding and resources from foreign partners. This includes partnerships with US allies in the global war on terrorism. The Under Secretary for Science and Technology of the Department of Homeland Security is authorized to establish the Science and Technology Homeland Security International Cooperative Program to facilitate international cooperative activities with countries like Israel, the United Kingdom, Canada, Australia, and Singapore. This includes developing mechanisms to strengthen American preparedness against threats to agriculture and public health from exotic diseases. The Science and Technology Directorate will establish the Homeland Security International Cooperative Program, led by a Director reporting to the Under Secretary. The Director will develop mechanisms for international cooperation in homeland security research and facilitate partnerships between US and non-US entities. The Science and Technology Directorate establishes the Homeland Security International Cooperative Program to facilitate partnerships in homeland security research. The Director coordinates activities with other Department components and relevant research agencies, supports international workshops and conferences, and does not limit program manager authority. The Homeland Security International Cooperative Program allows program managers to conduct international cooperative activities with coordination. $25,000,000 is authorized annually for these activities from the Directorate of Science and Technology budget. A report on partnerships formed must be submitted to Congress within 180 days of the section's enactment. The Homeland Security International Cooperative Program allows program managers to conduct international cooperative activities with coordination. A report on partnerships formed must be submitted to Congress within 180 days of the section's enactment, with updates every 5 years thereafter. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to include a new item after section 313. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to include a new item after section 313, promoting antiterrorism through international cooperation program. Passed the House of Representatives on September 26, 2006.
